To generate a hac1 null allele, one of the copies of HAC1 in the wild-type SK1 diploid LNY3 (Table I) was replaced with a hac1Δ100::URA3 allele (see 舠Experimental Procedures舡) (42Rothstein R. Methods Enzymol. 1983; 101: 202-211Google Scholar). Sporulation and subsequent tetrad analysis produced four viable spores, with thehac1Δ100::URA3 disruption allele segregating 2:2. However, spores carrying thehac1Δ100::URA3 mutation cosegregated with slow growth, thus forming only small colonies on YPD medium after 4 days at 30 °C (Fig. 1A). Microscopic examination revealed that thehac1Δ100::URA3 mutant yeast were larger, were somewhat elongated, and contained large vacuoles compared with wild-type cells (Fig. 1B). To verify that slow colony growth and increased cell size were a direct result of thehac1 deficiency, a wild-type HAC1 gene on a centromere-based plasmid pRS414-HAC1 was introduced into LNY542 (a/αhac1Δ100::URA3/+) (40Nikawa J. Yamashita S. Mol. Microbiol. 1992; 6: 1441-1446Google Scholar). After sporulation and tetrad analysis, we found that the growth rate and cell size of both wild-type and hac1 spore clones harboring pRS414-HAC1 were comparable, indicating that these phenotypes were a consequence of hac1 deficiency. Several lines of evidence indicate that this deletion was not a neomorphic allele. First, thehac1Δ100::URA3 allele removed most of the coding region including the entire DNA binding domain and leucine zipper, rendering it unlikely that any residual activity remained. Second, a second hac1Δ allele,hac1Δ200::LEU2 (LNY545, Table I), which extended the deleted region to remove both the initiator codon and the promoter, produced phenotypes identical to those conferred byhac1Δ100::URA3 (data not shown). Furthermore, both alleles were fully recessive to wild type, which is inconsistent with expression of a neomorphic mutation. Finally, we created hac1Δ100::URA3 strains in the W303 genetic background and found that these strains did not exhibit the SK-specific phenotypes, but were defective for the UPR (see below). To confirm that Hac1p activity was eliminated, we analyzed the SK1 and W303 hac1Δ100::URA3 stains for phenotypes known to be conferred by hac1 null mutations.hac1 mutants are inositol auxotrophs and are defective in the UPR. To monitor the UPR, we assayed for growth in the presence of tunicamycin (44Elbein A.D. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1981; 6: 219-221Google Scholar). Whereas wild-type strains from both genetic backgrounds were able to form colonies on medium containing 1 ॖg/ml tunicamycin, hac1Δ100::URA3 mutants in either background did not grow (Fig.2A). Furthermore, tunicamycin-stimulated induction of a UPRE-dependent ॆ-galactosidase reporter gene was defective inhac1Δ100::URA3 mutants derived from both SK1 and W303 genetic backgrounds (data not shown). Wild-type W303 strains were inositol prototrophs; however, isogenichac1Δ100::URA3 mutants grew very poorly in the absence of inositol, as previously described (Fig.2B) (25Cox J.S. Chapman R.E. Walter P. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1997; 8: 1805-1814Google Scholar, 45Sugiyama M. Nikawa J. J. Bacteriol. 2001; 183: 4985-4993Google Scholar). Surprisingly, wild-type SK1 strains were significantly compromised for growth in the absence of inositol. However, this limited growth capacity was completely abolished in the presence of hac1Δ100::URA3 (Fig.2B, top right). Thus, both W303 and SK1 hac1Δ100::URA3 strains are inositol auxotrophs. Northern blot analysis was used to directly monitor the UPR (Fig.2C). Under normal growth conditions, the unspliced form ofHAC1 mRNA was detectable in wild-type strains and the spliced form accumulated after UPR induction by tunicamycin treatment (11Cox J.S. Walter P. Cell. 1996; 87: 391-404Google Scholar, 14Kawahara T. Yanagi H. Yura T. Mori K. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1997; 8: 1845-1862Google Scholar). As expected, HAC1-derived message was not detectable under any conditions in thehac1Δ100::URA3 mutants. Tunicamycin-induced expression of KAR2, a UPR target gene, was abolished in the hac1Δ100::URA3mutants compared with wild-type strains. Similarly, induction ofINO1 was defective in hac1 strains. The phenotypes and expression patterns observed in our hac1Δmutants demonstrate that these were indeed null alleles. In fact, this study also revealed that INO1 induction in wild-type SK1 strains is very weak compared with that in W303 strains, and may explain the poor growth of the SK1 strains in the absence of inositol. It is possible that the inositol auxotrophy inherent in SK1 strains may contribute to the slow colony growth and increased cell size associated with SK1 hac1Δ mutants. However, this is not likely because supplementing the medium with excess inositol did not suppress the phenotype in the SK1 background (data not shown). In addition, because both wild-type and hac1 mutant SK1 cells grow well in the medium containing inositol (Fig. 2B), inositol metabolism is likely not defective under these conditions. In addition, overexpression of Kar2p did not rescue the poor growth of wild-type SK1 strains in the absence of inositol (Fig. 2B,bottom). Therefore, it is unlikely that the phenotype we report here is synthetic phenotype of the UPR and inositol biosynthetic pathways. To further characterize the SK1 hac1Δ100::URA3mutants, we backcrossed the spore clones derived from tetrad analysis of LNY3 (+/+) and LNY542 (hac1Δ100::URA3/+). Tetrads derived from SK1 strains characteristically displayed high viability (997) and 2:2 segregation of all markers, as was the case for LNY3 (Table II, line 1). Likewise, diploid strains heterozygous forhac1Δ100::URA3 (LNY542) that were generated by one-step gene replacement also produced tetrads with four viable spores (Fig. 1A). A total of 55 tetrads were analyzed; 215 of the 220 spores were viable, and the heterozygous markers (hac1Δ100::URA3 andMAT) segregated 2:2, as expected (Table II, line 2). Unusual genetic behavior was observed, however, upon tetrad analysis on strains generated by cross of SK1hac1Δ100::URA3 spore clones to wild-type SK1 haploids (Table II, line 3). First, spore viability was poor; only 146 of the expected 460 spores dissected formed colonies (327), and viability was found to be independent of theHAC1 or MAT genotype.
